body: I blinked and you fixed it! Thanks so much!

Hi there! We are currently testing the Sidekiq 7.1.4 > 7.1.5 update in our codebase, and we suspect this change might have something to do with an issue we see when applying the update. In our case, a workflow needs to run a `done` callback on _success_. 

We have a test that will verify that the `done` method on the expected class will be called (using RSpec mock verifications), which used to work correctly before but is now failing.

I can't share the actual code here, but this is something very similar to what we're running:

```ruby
it "tests the worker sequence triggered by the workflow" do
  Sidekiq::Testing.inline! do
    expect(WorkerA).to receive(:perform_async).once.ordered
    expect(WorkerB).to receive(:perform_async).once.ordered
    expect(WorkerC).to receive(:perform_async).once.ordered
    # etc.
    
    # This is the assertion that's failing with 7.1.5
    expect_any_instance_of(described_class).to receive(:done) 

    described_class.perform_async(date)
  end
end
```

Could it be related to the change on this PR?

The following example reproduces the same implementation structure we have in the workflow, where we will create a workflow and then batches to run each worker:

```ruby
require 'rails_helper'

Sidekiq::Testing.inline!

Sidekiq::Testing.server_middleware do |chain|
  chain.add Sidekiq::Batch::Server
end

class Workflow
  include Sidekiq::Worker

  def perform
    start
  end

  def start
    workflow = Sidekiq::Batch.new
    workflow.on(:success, 'Workflow#done')
    workflow.jobs do
      step = Sidekiq::Batch.new
      step.jobs do
        WorkflowWorker.perform_async
      end
    end
  end

  def done(_status, _options)
    puts "Workflow#done"
  end
end

class WorkflowWorker
  include Sidekiq::Worker

  def perform
    puts "WorkflowWorker#perform"
  end
end

RSpec.describe Workflow do
  describe "#perform" do
    it "executes all steps in the workflow" do
      described_class.perform_async
    end
  end
end
```

The spec at the bottom launches the workflow, reproducing the issue I was talking about in my previous comment, where the `WorkflowWorker#done` callback is never called.

Naturally, our actual workflow is much more convoluted, where more workers are executed per batch, and new batches are added dynamically in a series of steps, but this example above is a minimal sample of the most important features that reproduces the error we're seeing.
Looks like it's the nesting that's the issue. A callback directly on the `step` batch seems to work fine.

I think the net result of my investigation is that you can't use inline mode to execute nested batches. It doesn't work because the batch code requires the creating code to finish the `jobs` block before callbacks can be safely created, but that doesn't happen because the jobs execute immediately, before the `jobs` block finishes.
...and it turns out I think I can fix this by sending the parent data to Redis before executing the child jobs.

Hi @mperham! We've seen that 7.1.6 has been rolled out recently, but we still see the same issue [mentioned here](https://github.com/sidekiq/sidekiq/issues/6057#issuecomment-1748886574). Is this something that you're planning on fixing in an upcoming version?
Thanks, @mperham. That one did the trick! ðŸ™‡
@mperham is there any chance of this getting backported to  Sidekiq Pro 3.7.1?
3.7.1 is out of support. Y'all need to upgrade.

> 3.7.1 is out of support. Y'all need to upgrade.

@mperham what about backporting to sidekiq-pro 5.5.8?
